Variable created specifically for GENEVA. Documentation regarding the source for this variable is not available.

Because diabetes was detected only at visits, the most appropriate way to use time to incident diabetes is as an interval censored variable. DMLEFT and DMRIGHT define the interval. Variable created specifically for GENEVA. Documentation regarding the source for this variable is not available.

variable.description: Redefined supine ankle SBP [systolic blood pressure] at visit 1
Redefined supine ankle SBP [systolic blood pressure] at visit 1
Redefined supine brachial SBP [systolic blood pressure] at visit 1
Redefined supine brachial SBP [systolic blood pressure] at visit 1

variable.comment: At the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] examination visits arm and ankle systolic blood pressures were measured on resting subjects using the Dinamap 1846 SX. Brachial artery systolic pressures were measured in the right arm every five minutes during the carotid ultrasound examination. Posterior tibial artery systolic pressures were measured two times 5 to 8 minutes apart in one randomly selected leg. The ABI was calculated by dividing the average of the two ankle pressure measurements by the average of the first two brachial pressure readings (1, 2). The correlation between the duplicate blood pressure readings was 0.92 in the leg and 0.90 in the arm. The mean absolute difference between the duplicate readings was 0.5 mmHg (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.3-0.6) in the leg and 3.0 mmHg (95% CI 2.8-3.2) in the arm. Presence or absence of (PAD) was defined as an ABI less than 0.90 in men and less than 0.85 in women.

At the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] examination visits arm and ankle systolic blood pressures were measured on resting subjects using the Dinamap 1846 SX. Brachial artery systolic pressures were measured in the right arm every five minutes during the carotid ultrasound examination. Posterior tibial artery systolic pressures were measured two times 5 to 8 minutes apart in one randomly selected leg. The ABI was calculated by dividing the average of the two ankle pressure measurements by the average of the first two brachial pressure readings (1, 2). The correlation between the duplicate blood pressure readings was 0.92 in the leg and 0.90 in the arm. The mean absolute difference between the duplicate readings was 0.5 mmHg (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.3-0.6) in the leg and 3.0 mmHg (95% CI 2.8-3.2) in the arm. Presence or absence of (PAD) was defined as an ABI less than 0.90 in men and less than 0.85 in women.

variable.comment: Although the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] study has extensive quality assurance steps in place, the ARIC dataset may contain values that appear nonsensical or extreme. It is the responsibility of individual investigators to check for such values and decide how they are to be handled in the context of a particular analysis.

Although the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] study has extensive quality assurance steps in place, the ARIC dataset may contain values that appear nonsensical or extreme. It is the responsibility of individual investigators to check for such values and decide how they are to be handled in the context of a particular analysis.

Weight for derived average far wall thickness (L opt)
variable.comment: The weights are fractions (proportion of sites, out of 6, available for the calculations, so the values correspond to 1/6, 2/6, 3/6, 4/6, 5/6, 6/6). They are a measure of precision. Regression models using the ultrasound measurements as dependent variables will usually be more precise if weighted regression is used.

Diabts22 [diabetes - lower cut point 140 mg/dL, phd2067] using chmb07=126
Fasting time of 8 hours or more, Definition 2, at visit 2
Fasting time of 8 hours or more, Definition 2, at visit 2
Redefined supine brachial SBP [systolic blood pressure] at visit 3
Redefined supine brachial SBP [systolic blood pressure] at visit 3

variable.comment: At the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] examination visits arm and ankle systolic blood pressures were measured on resting subjects using the Dinamap 1846 SX. Brachial artery systolic pressures were measured in the right arm every five minutes during the carotid ultrasound examination. Posterior tibial artery systolic pressures were measured two times 5 to 8 minutes apart in one randomly selected leg. The ABI was calculated by dividing the average of the two ankle pressure measurements by the average of the first two brachial pressure readings (1, 2). The correlation between the duplicate blood pressure readings was 0.92 in the leg and 0.90 in the arm. The mean absolute difference between the duplicate readings was 0.5 mmHg (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.3-0.6) in the leg and 3.0 mmHg (95% CI 2.8-3.2) in the arm. Presence or absence of (PAD) was defined as an ABI less than 0.90 in men and less than 0.85 in women.

At the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] examination visits arm and ankle systolic blood pressures were measured on resting subjects using the Dinamap 1846 SX. Brachial artery systolic pressures were measured in the right arm every five minutes during the carotid ultrasound examination. Posterior tibial artery systolic pressures were measured two times 5 to 8 minutes apart in one randomly selected leg. The ABI was calculated by dividing the average of the two ankle pressure measurements by the average of the first two brachial pressure readings (1, 2). The correlation between the duplicate blood pressure readings was 0.92 in the leg and 0.90 in the arm. The mean absolute difference between the duplicate readings was 0.5 mmHg (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.3-0.6) in the leg and 3.0 mmHg (95% CI 2.8-3.2) in the arm. Presence or absence of (PAD) was defined as an ABI less than 0.90 in men and less than 0.85 in women.

Brachial artery systolic pressures were measured in the right arm every five minutes during the carotid ultrasound examination. Posterior tibial artery systolic pressures were measured two times 5 to 8 minutes apart in one randomly selected leg. The ABI was calculated by dividing the average of the two ankle pressure measurements by the average of the first two brachial pressure readings (1, 2). The correlation between the duplicate blood pressure readings was 0.92 in the leg and 0.90 in the arm. The mean absolute difference between the duplicate readings was 0.5 mmHg (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.3-0.6) in the leg and 3.0 mmHg (95% CI 2.8-3.2) in the arm. Presence or absence of (PAD) was defined as an ABI less than 0.90 in men and less than 0.85 in women.

At the ARIC [The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities] examination visits arm and ankle systolic blood pressures were measured on resting subjects using the Dinamap 1846 SX. Brachial artery systolic pressures were measured in the right arm every five minutes during the carotid ultrasound examination. Posterior tibial artery systolic pressures were measured two times 5 to 8 minutes apart in one randomly selected leg. The ABI was calculated by dividing the average of the two ankle pressure measurements by the average of the first two brachial pressure readings (1, 2). The correlation between the duplicate blood pressure readings was 0.92 in the leg and 0.90 in the arm. The mean absolute difference between the duplicate readings was 0.5 mmHg (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.3-0.6) in the leg and 3.0 mmHg (95% CI 2.8-3.2) in the arm. Presence or absence of (PAD) was defined as an ABI less than 0.90 in men and less than 0.85 in women.
